II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
A. 
 
2. 
For  years,  Pakistan  has  struggled  to  achieve  universal  primary  education  (classes  1-5) 
especially  in  rural  areas  and  for  females.  Throughout  the  1990s,  gross  enrollment  rates  for 
primary schooling increased from about 64% to 72%, while during the same period literacy rates 
for those over age 10 years increased from about 34% to 45%. Enrollments in rural areas have 
increased from 30% to 40%, while the gender gap has narrowed in favor of girls from about 40% 
to  30%  during  the  same  period.  These  accomplishments  have  taken  place  while  overall 
population  growth  has  expanded  at  about  2%  per  annum,  implying  that  enrollment  growth  has 
averaged  almost  3%  per  year.  In  general,  Pakistan  made  progress  in  spite  of  the  Asian  Crisis, 
which limited growth in the economy and accompanying curtailment of resources for education. 
This  was  in  part  due  specifically  to  the  externally  assisted  Social  Action  Program  (SAP)  and 
accompanying  investment  projects  implemented  especially  in  the  early  1990s  to  upgrade 
schools.1  
 
The  province  of  Sindh  accounts  for  about  25%  of  the  total  class  1-8  elementary  school-
3. 
aged  children  in  Pakistan.  Primary  school  enrollments  in  Sindh  mirror  those  for  the  nation,  as 
about 67% of eligible students in Sindh attended classes 1-5 primary schools in 2000. However, 
only 38% of 12-14 year olds in Sindh who graduated from primary schools progress to classes 6-
8. This number is below the national average and, more importantly, has been dropping over the 
past 8 years from about 50% to 38% due to lack of expansion to accommodate larger cohorts of 
primary school graduates. Furthermore, the private sector accounts for about about one third of 
the classes 6-8 enrollment in Sindh, of whom almost all come from urban areas and families with 
income above the median. The public sector school system accounts for about two thirds of class 
6-8 enrollment mostly from small towns and villages, where children come from poor families. The 
public  elementary  school  system  is  pro-poor  because  it  meets  the  needs  of  the  poor  in  rural 
communities. In the absence of private girls schools in rural areas, girls must rely on the public 
system  for  education.  It  is  understaffed  due  to  difficulties  in  providing  class  1-8  schools  in  rural 
communities,  where  attitudes  toward  education,  especially  for  girls,  are  often  not  conducive  to 
school attendance. In Sindh, inequities between the public and private elementary system mirror 
the general inequities between rural and urban households. Because of the low quality of public 
schooling,  many  students  from  poor  families  are  gravitating  towards  the  madrasahs,  where 
education is often narrowly focused on religious studies to the exclusion of broader subjects. 
 
4. 
Based  on  an  analysis  of  household  surveys  and  social  impact  assessments,  Sindh 
requested  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  help  accelerate  the  expansion  of  class  1-8 
elementary  education  to  meet  the  Millennium  Goals  to  provide  a  strong  foundation  for  pro-poor 
economic  recovery  and  poverty  reduction.  Sindh  wishes  to  follow  the  example  of  Punjab 
Province,  which  already  provides  public  elementary  education.  With  only  about  38%  of

majority of the two million eligible 10-12 year olds are exposed to new ideas through schooling. 
Only when the majority of Sindh children at a fairly young age are exposed to modern ideas and

B. 
 
5. 
Class  1-8  elementary  education  in  Sindh  faces  several  major  constraints.  Administrative 
capacity  has  traditionally  been  weak  and  poorly  financed,  giving  priority  to  classes  1-5  primary 
schools.  Social  service  delivery  has  been  inefficient,  top  down,  and  lacking  local  control.  Under 
the devolution of powers to districts that occurred in August 2001, various levels of government 
including  districts,  subdistricts  and  union  councils  have  had  their  staff  increased  and  provided 
with general training in the new rules and procedures. Administration and funding decisions have 
been  delegated  so  that  communities  and  schools  have  more  autonomy  in  prioritizing  needs. 
Nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  community  volunteers,  and  school  management 
committees (SMCs) have been given more leeway to work as stakeholders to strengthen schools. 
Institutional reforms under devolution have given authority to elected officials in combination with 
strengthening  of  SMCs  and  school  development  funds  (SDFs)  through  revised  guidelines  for 
staffing assignments, auditing, and planning. An example of local delegation of decision making 
includes  training  in  planning  and  monitoring  of  school  improvement  so  that  rehabilitation  and 
upgrading primary to elementary schools can be made based on need (Appendix 2).  
 
Under  SAP,  multisector  approaches  to  education  policy  planning  and  budgeting  took 
6. 
shape  for  the  first  time.  From  this  approach,  the  federal  and  provincial  governments  along  with 
external  aid  agencies  began  developing  sector-wide  approaches  employing  annual  operational 
plans  and  data  collection  from  educational  management  information  systems  in  each  province. 
ADB is contributing to these efforts by focusing on Sindh province, where external assistance is 
weak but where the need is great and government commitment is high. This has led to looking at 
a long-term strategy to rationalize assistance under the newly emerging devolved social service 
delivery  with  emphasis  on  the  elementary  school  subsector.  The  process  approach  to  the 
subsector supports the Millennium Goals of universal elementary education by 2015. It goes hand 
in  hand  with  the  implementation  of  devolution,  as  ADB  is  reinforcing  district  education  plans  for 
the  subsector  that  will  yield  a  performance-based  monitoring  of  school  facilities,  staffing,  and 
resources tied to growth in school enrollments. ADB assistance to Sindh will be shared with other 
provinces  and  with  other  aid  agencies  working  in  other  subsectors,  so  lessons  learned  will  get 
disseminated widely. The investment project fits well with the wider aims of devolution and with 
the subsector-wide efforts of ADB and other agencies to strengthen citizens' boards and district 
level  management  including  ombudsmen  and  to  provide  checks  and  balances  between  elected 
officials, NGOs, and school beneficiaries. 
 
7. 
Finally, performance-based monitoring of the education system needs to more closely link 
community awareness of school relevance to school enrollment drives. Sindh has an educational 
database,  but  it  does  not  disaggregate  enrollments  for  the  elementary  school  sector  or 
disaggregate  growth  by  district.  Furthermore,  inputs  are  not  compared  with  outputs,  so  system 
efficiency cannot be measured. ADB efforts to rationalize the elementary school system will help 
to document school improvement in a cost-effective manner so that district education plans can 
be developed and targets measured. This will help to determine the precise staffing requirements 
based  on  school  demand,  and  will  also  allow  educators  to  determine  the  effect  of  interventions 
such as school stipends on enrollment growth, especially for female students in classes 6-8.  
 

   3

The government strategy of both Pakistan and Sindh Province are designed to link basic 
8. 
education to poverty reduction, especially through the Education for All targets set by UNESCO2 
and subscribed to by the governments. Under the Interim Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper,3 the 
Federal Government has linked poverty reduction to elementary education through social capital 
creation to sustain good citizenship, job creation, consumer information, and reproductive health. 
The  federal  and  provincial  governments  have  initiated  the  Education  Sector  Reform4  (ESR) 
Action Program, which aims to raise gross enrollments as well as expand primary to elementary 
education.  The  ESR  is  the  Government’s  education  policy  and  includes  elementary  education, 
madrassah  education,  and  support  for  district  education  offices  and  SMCs.  Development 
expenditure  gaps  identified  under  the  ESR  will  be  funded  by  external  grants  and  through  this 
project  in  the  form  of  development  funds  for  innovative  programs  such  as  preprimary 
(kindergarten)  and  elementary  education,  and  community  mobilization 
through  school 
development  funds.  The  Project  will  strengthen  ongoing  programs  to  support  local  teacher 
recruitment and training, facilities and equipment upgrading, and district planning.  
 
The Government already has initiated its Devolution of Power5 plan for local government, 
9. 
which  is  expected  to  fundamentally  alter  the  way  educational  service  delivery  is  provided 
(Appendix 3). Devolution supports governance through greater transparency, an increase in the 
number  of  stakeholders,  greater  accountability  including  financial  auditing,  and  civil  service 
reform  devolving  more  staff  to  the  local  level.  The  Project  will  strengthen  many  of  these  goals 
through  provision  of  additional  funds  and  training  to  increase  stakeholder  participation  and  to 
raise  the  level  of  educational  services  to  meet  stakeholder  expectations.  Equally  important,  the 
Project  will  support  institutional  strengthening  at  the  provincial,  district,  and  subdistrict  levels

PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

 
46. 
Sindh  wants  to  develop  economically  and  socially  by  reducing  poverty  and  raising  its 
human resource base so that rural areas can benefit from economic activity generated in Karachi, 
Hyderabad, and Nawabshah. To accomplish this, Sindh must raise the province’s education level 
from the class 1-5 primary school system to a class 1-8 elementary school system. The Project 
will  support  all  existing  2,000  class  1-8  public  elementary  schools  and  provide  upgrading  from 
primary  to  elementary  for  an  additional  1,400  selected  schools,  especially  in  rural  areas  (65% 
female) leading to a province-wide public elementary system that will eventually serve 55% of all 
eligible  10-12  year  olds.  Consequently,  about  500,000  existing  class  6-8  public  school  students 
will  benefit  from  the  project  along  with  an  additional  168,000  students  who  will  have  the 
opportunity to attend classes 6-8 for a total of 668,000 students enrolled annually in classes 6-8 
by  2009.  In  addition,  the  Project  will  provide  faculties,  furniture,  equipment,  learning  materials, 
and  training  to  200,000  class  1-5  students  in  1,400  project  schools.  Under  the  program, 
approximately  1,000  schools  will  commence  preprimary  classes  for  approximately  30,000

preschoolers (50% female). Selected madrasah schools will be provided teacher training in class 
6-8 core subjects.

SECTOR/SUBSECTOR ANALYSIS 

 
1. 
Social  sector  service  delivery  for  education  has  lagged  behind  targets  set  by  the 
Government for the past 10 years despite Social Action Program (SAP) policies to protect the 
level of social sector spending. Reasons for the poor performance include the global economic 
downturn,  political  developments  in  the  region  and  a  lack  of  management  capacity  needed  to 
coordinate  change.  The  Government  of  Sindh  recognizes  that  a  strong  elementary  school 
system  serving  the  majority  of  students  is  essential  to  raise  the  prospects  for  economic 
development,  social  mobility,  education,  and  job  opportunities  to  reduce  poverty.  For  Sindh, 
public provision of educational services is essential to ensure an important public good, ensure 
equity  across  all  the  districts  and  correct  market  failures  where  the  private  education  sector 
siphons off those with ability to pay. Sindh Province is especially at risk of not employing basic 
education  to  reduce  poverty  especially  outside  Karachi,  where  65%  of  the  30  million  Sindh 
population  reside  in  underserved  rural  areas.  Decentralization  of  public  services  is  viewed  as 
one way to help ensure that decisions are taken closest to those who benefit from education—
decisions that lead to long-term poverty reduction in communities (Figure A3.1). 
 
2. 
The  Sindh  education  system  caters  to  6.0  million  children  aged  5-10  (primary)  and 
another  2.0  million  aged  11-13  (middle)  for  a  total  cohort  of  8  million  elementary  school 
students. At present about 65% of the primary school age cohort attend school while 38% of the 
middle  school  age  group  are  enrolled.  There  is  a  small  but  high  quality  private  elementary 
education  system  operating  in  urban  areas,  especially  in  Karachi,  that  serves  the  middle  and 
upper classes. The private system caters to the upper 50% of income families and charges fees 
three to four times the amount charged to public school students. In contrast, the public school 
system is large but inefficiently organized and ineffectively operated. It serves rural areas where 
the population of school-going children is poor and scattered. Given the cultural impediments of 
meeting  the  needs  of  female  students  who  are  unable  to  travel  long  distances  from  home  to 
school, girls’ education is especially underserved by the public school system. According to the 
Pakistan  Household  Survey,  between  1997  and  1999  the  Asian  Crisis  impacted  on  the  gap 
between  the  urban  and  rural  in  terms  of  elementary  school  participation  rates,  with  a  lesser 
proportion  of  children  from  the  lowest  income  households  going  to  school  as  compared  with 
previous  years.  However,  while  boys  dropped  out  of  school  due  to  economic  hardship,  girls' 
enrollments actually grew. 
 
3. 
The  result  of  this  two-tier  elementary  education  system  in  Sindh  is  a  private  sector 
school  system  that  attracts  one  in  three  parents  who  can  afford  to  send  children  to  schools 
possessing  adequate  facilities,  staff  and  budgets.  The  public  school  system  caters  to  two  in 
three parents from the bottom 50% of the household income and those living in rural areas. The 
schools often lack facilities, staff, and adequate budgets, and students still must pay fees that 
can  amount  to  $30  each  year  for  books,  uniforms,  and  incidentals,  which  is  often  prohibitive. 
Sindh wants to develop a rationalized system of elementary schools for classes1-8 throughout 
the province that will serve both rural and urban areas and will complement the private sector 
system. Until a majority of the young are in school through class 8, exposure to new ideas and 
ways of doing things will not take root (Table A3.1). 
 
4. 
Based on enrollment projections, the Provincial Education Department estimates that an 
additional  250,000  students—two  thirds  of  them  girls—will  complete  class  5  in  the  coming  10 
years but will not be able to attend class 6 due to a shortage of available elementary schools in 
local communities. This number includes potential students who could be pulled into class 6 and 
beyond through upgrading primary schools to elementary schools. Along similar lines, estimates 
suggest that the internal efficiency of class 1-5 could be improved by 10% over the next 5 years 
to increase the number of class 5 public school leavers by 200,000, thereby contributing to the

5. 
Reasons  why  education  lags  in  rural  Sindh  are  several.  First,  there  has  not  been  a 
concerted  effort  to  map  school  enrollments,  school  locations  and  staff  deployment  throughout 
the  province.  The  educational  management  information  system  developed  under  the  SAP 
lacked  the  sophistication  needed  to  collect  statistics  annually,  and  political  interference  from 
provincial  politicians  affected  teacher  assignments,  which  was  not  picked  up  in  the  surveys. 
Second,  teacher  deployment  was  not  accurately  reflected  in  data  collection  and,  more 
importantly,  decisions  on  teacher  assignment  were  not  taken  at  the  local  level.  Consequently, 
communities had no control over teacher assignment or performance. Third, incentive systems 
for both teachers and communities did not exist and so communities lacked the ability to reward 
teacher performance and encourage parents to send their children to school regularly.  
 
6. 
Recognizing  these  failures,  the  Provincial  Education  Department  has  embarked  on  a 
program to map the existing 2,000 class 1-8 elementary schools to note location, coverage or 
catchment  area,  enrollments,  and  staff  resources.  Planning  for  expansion  of  schools  with  full 
classes  1-8  will  allow  unserved  communities  to  request  on  a  needs  basis  for  upgraded 
elementary  schools.  Efforts  are  under  way  to  strengthen  the  local  community  through  support 
for existing School Management Committees to make them important stakeholders in ensuring 
that schools function efficiently. The link between parents and community with local schools will 
be  critical  to  effective  networking  of  elementary  schools  in  Sindh  and  will  help  ensure 
community  involvement  to  take  decisions  based  on  need  to  improve  schools.  For  example, 
teacher  attendance  will  be  monitored  by  the  staff  management  committee  and  reported  to  the 
union council. Further, deployment of new teachers will be made at the district and local levels 
and not at the provincial offices (Table A3.3). 
 
7. 
The  Government  of  Sindh  views  poverty  reduction,  especially  among  the  rural 
population, as the key to boosting economic development outside of Karachi. Education plays 
an  important  role  to  create  the  social  capital  needed  by  the  poor  to  reach  their  maximum 
potential. Sindh's poverty framework includes physical asset creation including access to credit, 
social asset creation including education and nutrition, social safety nets and good governance 
including  devolution  of  power,  civil  service  reforms,  and  access  to  justice.  Education’s  role  in 
reducing poverty stems from providing opportunities for social and job mobility. Until a majority 
of the young are exposed to new ideas through schooling, it is unlikely that the population will 
have the skills and knowledge to escape poverty (Table A3.4).
